body.p: This page (and documentation) is available in the following languages:

Danish | Dutch | English | French | German | Hungarian | Indonesian | Italian | Japanese |
Russian | Spanish | Traditional Chinese

Welcome to the Gentoo Documentation Resources. This page will give you a quick overview on the documentation we provide. Most documentation is released under the Creative Commons - Attribution / Share Alike license, an open documentation license. All documentation should also be available in a printer-friendly format. To view this document, append ?style=printable to the URL.

If you find bugs in our documentation or have proposals, please use our Bugtracking System and fill in a bug report for "Docs-developer" or "Docs-user". These bug reports will then be handled by the Gentoo Documentation Project.

Our documentation is available in several languages. Although not all documents are translated, we do our best to keep them all up to date and provide our users with as much translated documentation as possible. If you want to help with our translation efforts, please contact Xavier Neys who is in charge of the internationalisation efforts.
As with every major project Gentoo has a FAQ too. We have first and foremost a couple of official FAQs maintained by the Gentoo Documentation Project:

ul.li: The Gentoo FAQ answers Frequently Asked Questions about Gentoo Linux with focus on x86 platforms.
The Gentoo PPC FAQ answers Frequently Asked Questions about Gentoo Linux on the PowerPC platform.
The Gentoo SPARC FAQ answers Frequently Asked Questions about Gentoo Linux on the SPARC platform.

body.p: Furthermore we have a very extensive collection of FAQs on our forums. To view those, go to http://forums.gentoo.org/viewforum.php?f=40.

The Gentoo Documentation Project has started with the Gentoo Handbook development. Currently, the first two parts (Installing Gentoo and Working with Gentoo) are finished and have reached the "official" stage. Users are encouraged to use the installation instructions from the Handbook and bug us with their experience (please use the Handbook component).
More information can be found on the Gentoo Handbook Effort homepage.

The installation related documentation provides information that can be useful during the installation of Gentoo Linux. This includes the part on "Installing Gentoo" in our Gentoo Handbook, as well as the older but still maintained architecture-related installation resources and tutorials that are to be followed during the installation.
The first part of our Gentoo Handbook explains how to install Gentoo on your system. Each architecture-specific version contains instructions for all users.
For experienced users we also have Quick Installation Reference documents:
Alpha-users are probably also interested in our Compaq Alpha Tools Guide, which explains how to set up the Compaq Tools package for Gentoo Alpha users.
AMD64-users should start with the AMD64 Technotes which contains information about the AMD64 Project, Installation Notes, Download Instructions and more.

For some people, the installation guide above doesn't suffice since their environment doesn't permit them to boot from a LiveCD. To anticipate their environments we provide the Alternative Installation Guide which lists the installation steps needed to install Gentoo from another medium (distribution, bootable CD, network boot, etc.).
Users interested in using LVM2 should read up our LVM2 Guide which explains the steps required to get your LVM2 scheme up and running.

As our installation instructions allow for great flexibility, there are many tips and tricks that can be persued during the installation. We have a Gentoo/x86 Installation Tips 'n Tricks document online (which also contains interesting Tips 'n Tricks for other architectures).
The Gentoo Linux 1.4 Upgrade Guide explains how to upgrade your Gentoo Linux 1.x systems to Gentoo Linux 1.4.
The Gentoo Upgrading Guide goes deeper into the motivation behind the easy-upgrading system Gentoo uses and provides more information about the so-called "profiles".
The Genkernel Guide intends to provide a reference of all the functions provided by genkernel.
With the help of our coLinux HOWTO you are able to run Gentoo from within Windows.
The Gentoo System Documentation contains several guides about what makes Gentoo Gentoo. This includes our init-system, Portage, USE-flags etc.
The Gentoo Handbook has a part on Working with Gentoo which contains information on Portage, USE flags, the Gentoo Init system and environment variables.

The Portage and Software chapter in the Gentoo Handbook briefly covers how to keep your packages up to date and how to maintain your installed software. In other words, this chapter tells you how to use emerge.

The Portage Manual provides a general overview of Portage, detailed configuration information and an end user guide to installing and maintaining packages using the Portage system. It is far more extended than the Portage User Guide.

The USE Flags chapter in the Gentoo Handbook introduces you to the ultimate tool for customizing Gentoo -- USE flags. This howto helps you decide which USE flags you need. It also describes the use of etcat to receive more verbose information regarding USE-flags on a package.
The Environment Variables chapter in the Gentoo Handbook explains how to manage environment variables (such as $PATH) and the dynamic linker cache easily.

The Initscripts chapter in the Gentoo Handbook details our system startup and service management scripts. Besides the regular initscript-related items it also covers initscript dependencies and support for virtuals.
The Kernel Guide lists the various kernel sources Gentoo provides. Most of these kernels are maintained by the Gentoo Kernel Project.

The System Administration Documentation contains tutorials and guides on how to install, configure and/or manage certain aspects of system administration. Although the focus is on Gentoo systems, several of these guides can very well be used by non-Gentoo users.

The Gentoo Security Guide explains how to harden a Gentoo Linux system against intruders and attacks. It contains general security information (securing services, designing firewalls, using IDS, kernel security etc.). For even tighter hardening please visit the Gentoo Hardened website.
The Prelinking Guide explains how to enhance your system using prelink. With prelinking, bigger applications start up faster.
The IPv6 Guide shows how to setup IPv6 under Gentoo Linux. IPv6 is the next Internet Protocol and is gaining popularity widely.

The User Mode Linux Guide shows how to use User-Mode Linux under Gentoo Linux. User Mode Linux (UML) provides a nice feature for Linux: Running Linux inside Linux (inside Linux inside Linux ...). With UML, you can easily create virtual setups.
The OpenMosix Howto describes step by step how you can create a farm of openmosix nodes (a cluster of several PCs).
The Diskless Howto describes step by step how you can set up diskless nodes with Gentoo.
The LTSP Guide explains how to setup a Linux Terminal Server with Gentoo.
The Distcc Guide informs you how to use distcc for distributed compilations with Gentoo Linux.
The DevFS Guide describes how DevFS works and how to administer it.
The Gentoo udev Guide describes the new device file management (using udev) which replaces DevFS and informs the reader how udev is integrated in Gentoo.
The Printing Howto is a comprehensive guide to Gentoo and printing.
The OpenAFS Guide documents the use and installation of OpenAFS, a distributed network-based file sharing technology.
The Virtual/Mailhost Postfix Howto is the essential guide for any postfix mail administrator. It covers the use of MySQL for virtual users, webbased e-mail software, mailinglist software etc.
The qmail/vpopmail Howto is a pretty useful guide for running a qmail based mail system. It focuses on remote access and encrypted communication.
The Gentoo/SPARC Netboot HOWTO describes how to setup a network booting environment for a Sun Microsystems SPARC or UltraSPARC based computer.
The Gentoo SPARC OpenBoot PROM reference Guide offers a guide to the SPARC OpenBoot system, available on all Sun Microsytsms SPARC/UltraSparc based computers.
The Quick SAMBA Howto gives you a step-by-step introduction to Samba and includes instructions on setting up an anti-virus checking for the Samba shares.

Gentoo is a volunteer-driven distribution. It is therefore vital to have high-quality development-related documentation available so that interested users can easily learn how to help in the development of their favorite distribution.

All developer-specific documentation, including but not limited to Ebuild and Eclass development, policies and such, has now been bundled in one awsome Gentoo Developer Handbook for your reading pleasure.
The Gentoo Linux Documentation Policy details current policy for the creation and editing of documentation.
The Contributing Ebuilds Guide explains how to submit user-authored ebuilds.
The GuideXML Guide documents the XML format used in Gentoo Linux's web-based documentation.
The Doc Developers' Tips & Tricks contains some pointers for documentation developers.
The CVS Tutorial documents the basics of using CVS, the Concurrent Versioning System.

ul.li: View our CVS repository if you need to look at our code and ebuilds.
More on the XML projects Gentoo has gone through.

body.p: For people who like to get a short overview on available documentation, here it is :)

ti.uri: Gentoo SPARC OpenBoot PROM Reference Guide
